Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Role of Activity-dependent Mechanisms in Stabilization of Spine Synapses
Award.AbstractNarration: One of the most remarkable events in development of the nervous system is the construction of the diverse and complicated array of neural circuits that underlie behavior, from the simple circuit of a motor reflex to the complex circuits that underlie learning and memory. The research objective of this project is to understand how neural circuits are initially established during development and how they are modified by sensory experiences. Specifically, the goal of this project is to identify the patterns of neural activity that act to stabilize newly formed circuit connections in the mammalian brain. Advanced imaging techniques and electrophysiology will be used to stimulate individual synaptic connections and to monitor their strength and stability, in order to identify those activity patterns that lead to stabilization of neural circuits. Neural activity patterns that lead to increase in the strength of individual synaptic connections are expected also to lead to stabilization of circuit connections. Results from these experiments will advance our understanding of the mechanisms by which neural circuits are established and stabilized during development of the nervous system. In addition, this research project will provide training opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students in the laboratory. The educational objective of this project is to develop an outreach program at UC Davis in order to advance public awareness about the progress and benefits of brain research and to encourage grade school students to choose scientific career paths. This program will serve to increase participation in outreach activities from a large and diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students with the goal that these students will be encouraged to continue outreach activities throughout their scientific careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary research goal of this grant was to further our understanding of how new synaptic connections are established between nerve cells during development of the mammalian brain. Specifically, we examined the neural activity patterns and signaling mechanisms that drive the initiation and stabilization of new circuit connections in the hippocampus, a part of the brain with a central role in learning and memory.

This project had intellectual merit in that these experiments led to several significant findings that increase our understanding of how the brain is wired up during development and how we learn as adults. In one set of studies, we focused on the signaling mechanisms that regulate the outgrowth of new dendritic spines, microscopic protrusions from neuronal dendrites that serve as the postsynaptic site for most excitatory synaptic connections in the cortex. We made an unexpected and exciting discovery that new spine outgrowth is regulated by the proteasome. We found that acute inhibition of the proteasome decreased activity-dependent growth of new spines. Moreover, we showed that NMDA-type glutamate receptors and the kinase CaMKII act in the same pathway as the proteasome to facilitate new spine growth. Furthermore, we identified the serine 120 of the Rpt6 subunit of the proteasome as a critical regulatory site for activity-dependent spine outgrowth. Current studies are focused on identification and characterization of the proteins that are degraded by the proteasome in order to initiate spine outgrowth. Results from these studies provide key insights into the molecules and mechanisms that support the initial growth of connections during neural circuit development and in learning.

In a second set of studies, we focused on the neural activity patterns and signaling mechanisms that regulate the stabilization of nascent dendritic spines into new circuit connections. We found that high-frequency glutamatergic stimulation, which leads to synaptic strengthening, also leads to the long-term stabilization of new synaptic connections. We determined that activity- dependent spine stabilization requires signaling through NMDA-type glutamate receptors and their interaction with the kinase, CaMKII, and is specific for stimuli that induce synaptic strengthening. Our findings demonstrate for the first time that, in addition to enhancing the efficacy of preexisting synapses, high-frequency glutamatergic stimulation promotes the transition of nascent spines from a short-lived, transient state to a longer-lived, persistent state. Current studies are focused on further defining the signaling pathways and molecules that mediate activity-induced spine stabilization. Results from these studies significantly advance our understanding of the molecules and mechanisms that support the stabilization of new synaptic connections during neural circuit development and in learning.

This project had broader impacts in that the primary educational goal of this grant was to develop a Brain Awareness Week outreach program at UC Davis in order to advance public awareness about the progress and benefits of brain research and to encourage grade school students to choose scientific career paths. Each year the outreach program involved three components: (1) grade school outreach, with a particular emphasis on local grade school with significant minority populations, (2) an interactive neuroscience educational booth at the local farmer’s market, and (3) a public neuroscience lecture. This program has served to increase participation in outreach activities from a large and diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students with the goal that these students will be encouraged to continue outreach activities throughout their scientific careers.
